quotes.quote: Little minds are tamed and subdued by misfortune; but great minds rise above them.
A few great minds are enough to endow humanity with monstrous power, but a few great hearts are not enough to make us worthy of using it.
As great minds have the faculty of saying a great deal in a few words, so lesser minds have a talent of talking much, and saying nothing.
Great minds always tend to see virtue in misfortune.
Failures and mistakes are definitely the greatest teachers to all great minds.
Every great mind seeks to labor for eternity. All men are captivated by immediate advantages; great minds alone are excited by the prospect of distant good.
No great mind has ever existed without a touch of madness.
Great minds think alike, but lovers think as one.
High aims form high characters, and great objects bring out great minds.
Great minds that are healthy are never considered geniuses, while this sublime qualification is lavished on brains that are often inferior but are slightly touched by madness.
Oblivion is a second death, which great minds dread more than the first.
Great minds find beauties and appreciate it. Average minds find commonalities and compare. Small minds find the problems and criticize.
While small minds were bragging about their material possessions, great minds were busy expanding their assets.
Great minds with great ideas usually share in the midst of their persecution
A great mind is not sharpened by consorting with lesser minds.
Great minds tend toward banality. It is the noblest effort of individualism. But it implies a sort of modesty, which is so rare that it is scarcely found except in the greatest, or in beggars.
Great advantages are often attended with great inconveniences, and great minds called to severe trials.
Great errors seldom originate but with men of great minds.
The most characteristic mark of a great mind is to choose some one important object, and pursue it for life.
Small mind competes, big mind collaborates and great mind encompasses.
Little minds try to solve the matters through violence and darkness; great minds try to solve the matters through love and light!
Silence is sometimes more significant and sublime than the most noble and most expressive eloquence, and is on many occasions the indication of a great mind.
It is the sign of a great mind to dislike greatness, and prefer things in measure to things in excess.
Small minds are concerned with the extraordinary, great minds with the ordinary.
To live for a time close to great minds is the best kind of education.
Great minds must be ready not only to take opportunities, but to make them.
Only great minds can afford a simple style.
A great mind becomes a great fortune.
The great mind knows the power of gentleness.
Great minds discuss ideas; average minds discuss events; small minds discuss people.
